{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3536944,"name":"AfterTen","username":"AfterTen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/afterten/{size}/11780_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-23T03:23:36.706Z","cooked":"

Implemented MaxMotion on our rotating arm.
My understanding is MaxMotion is very similar to WPILib Profiled PID controller with Trapezoidal constraints.

What we experienced was that as we tried to move our arm to a new set point that was quite a distance away (over 180 degrees) it was blocked from moving for 2.5 seconds at the start. The blockage gave way and the arm then spun wildly past it’s limits.

Damage was done and repaired.

We suspect we know the theoretical reason this happened but since this is a black box algorithm we’re not sure if we are missing anything in the setup or execution of MaxMotion that might have automatically prevented this.

Could other comment if they’ve seen this behavior and how they adjusted for it?

Would WPILib’s implementation have performed better under this circumstance?

Is there a best practice on what we should be programmatically monitoring to catch this early and shut the arm down?

Like we could monitor the arm position and if it is not moving when it’s expected to be moving shut the arm down and try and figure out a recovery procedure.

yeah, that exact thing (an outer monitor) is a great idea.

you could also use that same pattern (and the same exact code) for automatic preflight testing.

one thing that might have been happening, and would make the situation worse, is using the “I” term in PID, without limiting the integral “wind up.”

This is a poor take, if you were 20% of the way when the mechanism got stuck (80% left), the P term could also be large (won’t grow like I would) and could cause just as much damage being in high stall.

AfterTen:

Would WPILib’s implementation have performed better under this circumstance?

Yes. The design of MaxMotion position control makes it difficult to apply an accurate dynamic gravity linearization, or velocity/acceleration feedforward terms.

It is also difficult to get enough telemetry out of it to tune the feedback well.

It is disappointing to find that the crippling problems with SmartMotion seem to have been replaced with a different set of equally-crippling problems with MaxMotion. I think everyone would be better served by removing the feature…

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-02-23T18:15:27.853Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":66,"readers_count":65,"score":28.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492811,"topic_slug":"rev-maxmotion-or-wpilib-profiled-pid-and-blocked-mechanism-causes-damage","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53190,"username":"truher","name":"joel truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/rev-maxmotion-or-wpilib-profiled-pid-and-blocked-mechanism-causes-damage/492811/7","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3537312,"name":"Todd","username":"Todd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/todd/{size}/184725_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-23T18:25:04.471Z","cooked":"

I haven’t used the MAX Motion controller much, so I might be misinterpreting this - but I think you’ll find that the trajectory continues to run into the future even though your mechanism has come to a halt, so while the P error is not accumulating like an I term is, your total error is still increasing, you’re ‘underrunning’ the trajectory.

And then while the trajectory itself honors your acceleration and velocity constraints the PID does not, so the command can rapidly approach saturation.

This can be somewhat mitigated with limits on the output command and on the current, but it’s a pretty common weakness of this type of controller. I’m not certain if the REV API makes the error term available, but you could monitor it, or other similar parameters, as you’ve said, to override the mode in case of obstruction.
